When months with civilian fatalities relevant to the question serve the unit of analysis, 107 of  the 249 months on record have seen at least one fatality relevant to the question (42%). Between 2007 and 2016 this rate was higher (52%), than in the previous decade (40%). In the past two decades, 14 years (70%) have seen 4  (maximum number still possible for this year) or more months in which relevant fatalities were recorded. In the past decade this number was 9 (90%). As four months with relevant fatalities this year would necessarily include October, this suggests that the estimate should be higher than the base rate of approximately 50%.

Fatalities from violence against civilians/remote violence recorded for only one month in 2017 (April) and three months in 2016.  So put simply somewhere between 10 - 25% for October if that's our relevant time frame.   October tends to fall in the mid-range historically (in terms of seasonality).  No fatalities since April (not in the middle of a chain of events) so slight discount for that.  Putting more weight on 2017, but acknowledged dynamics related to upcoming elections, 15%.

Electoral violence prior to eclectic starts in Africa are ubiquitous.  In Zimbabwe violence is increasing over time; during September, large numbers (a range > 400) were assaulted but no fatalities occurred.  The dilemma is whether intimidation, threats and detentions will lead to fatalities satisfying the criteria for the fatality counts. Factionalism and authoritarian interaction among parties and citizens (i.e. members of ruling and contesting parties) provides us with a reasonable indicator of where levels of violence will increase.  Anecdotal evidence over the last four days such that militias serving as proxies of by both ruling and opposition parties are attacking its respective opponents and that factionalism within ZANUPF is reaching extreme levels, pointing toward further violence in the near future.
